div.p:
THe memory of the ju≈øt is ble≈ø≈øed, ≈øaith the Wi≈øeman, but the name of the the wicked
≈øhall rot. And ≈øurely the righteous ≈øhall bee had in everla≈øting remembrance, ≈øaith holy DAVID. Yet the Prophet ESAY complaines, That the righteous peri≈øh, and no man con≈øidereth it in heart: and mercifull men are taken away, and no man under≈øtandeth, That the righteous are taken away from the evill to come. In con≈øideration whereof, that I may not be culpable of the like reproofe, I will with the P≈øalmi≈øt, marke the upright man, and behold the ju≈øt, for the end of that man is peace. For thereby I ≈øhall learn how to dye comfortably. It may bee as a paterne or example to direct me and others in the houre of death. For eth wicked they dye either ≈øotti≈øhly,
impatiently, or de≈øperately.

Fir≈øt, ≈øotti≈øhly like blocks and idiots, having neither penitent feeling of their ≈øins, nor comfortable a≈ø≈øurance of ≈øalvation. Being like to Nabal, who≈øe heart ten daies before his death, died within him, and he was like a ≈øtone. Such men die like lambes, and yet ≈øhall bee a prey for the devouring Lion; they go quietly like fools to the ≈øtocks for correction.

Secondly, others die impatiently, who do not willingly bear the Lords correction de≈øerved by their ≈øins; but rage, fret, and murmure, as if God dealt too rigorou≈øly with them, and through impatiency will u≈øe unlawfull meanes for their recovery: as Ahaziah
did, who being ≈øicke, ≈øent me≈ø≈øengers to enquire of Baal zebub the god of Ekren, if he ≈øhould recover of his di≈øea≈øe.

Thirdly, others die de≈øperately, their con≈øciences accu≈øing them mo≈øt terribly for their ≈øins, without any hope of pardon; as Cain, who ≈øaid, my ≈øinne is greater then can be forgiven; or Iudas, who de≈øpairing of pardon for his ≈øin, in betraying our Saviour, went and hanged him≈øelfe. The con≈øciences of many wicked men lye quietly, and never trouble them all their life time, but are ≈øtirred up at their death, and then rage and torment them like a mad dogge which is lately awaked out of ≈øleepe. But the righteous
die mo≈øt comfortably, they beleeving in Chri≈øt, and having repented of their ≈øinnes, are a≈ø≈øured in their owne ≈øoules that all their ≈øinnes are pardoned in Chri≈øt: they wil make confe≈ø≈øion of their faith, and give te≈øtimony of their repentance unto others, for their comfort and example. They will patiently endure all the paines of their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe, as Iob did, knowing that all comes from the Lord, and that it is his fatherly correction, and a ≈øigne of his love, becau≈øe ‚Ä¢ e cha≈øteneth whom he loveth: yea, they receive their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe as the Lords me≈ø≈øenger, ≈øpeaking to their ≈øoules, as the Prophet I≈øaiah did to Hezekiah, Put thine hou≈øe in order, for thou ≈øhalt die and not live;
and therefore they prepare them≈øelves for another world. Ye ‚Ä¢ further, in their ≈øickne≈ø≈øe they can pray mo≈øt fervently, as King Hezekiah did, I≈øaiah 38. and then they will give mo≈øt fruitfull and comfortable in≈øtructions to tho≈øe which they leave behinde. As the Swan ≈øings mo≈øt ≈øweetly a little before his death; ≈øo the righteous ≈øpeake mo≈øt divinely a little before their end. Who≈øoever ≈øearcheth the Scriptures, may read the divine prophecy of Iacob unto the twelve Patriarches, Gene≈ø. 49. the holy ble≈ø≈øing of Mo≈øes upon the twelve tribes, Deut 33. the godly exhortation of Io≈øua to the people of I≈ørael plac ‚Ä¢ d by h ‚Ä¢ m in Canaan, Io≈ø. 23. the wi≈øe coun≈øell of
David unto Salomon, who was to ≈øucceed him in the kingdome: 1 King. 2. Who≈øoever readeth the Eccle≈øia≈øticall hi≈øtories, may not onely ≈øee the vertuous lives, but al≈øo the Chri≈øtian like ends of the Saints and Martyrs in the Church. And who≈øoever will be pre≈øent at the death of tho≈øe which truly feare God, may thereby learne how they them≈øelves ought to die: for when the outward man doth decay, the inward man is renewed more and more. They ≈øhew, that the neerer they doe approach unto their end, the neerer they draw toward heaven.

But in the≈øe our dayes many may be found, who either do not
at all con≈øider the death of the righteous, or el≈øe doe con≈øider it ami≈ø≈øe. Though it bee a matter worth con≈øideration; yet ≈øome doe not con≈øider it at all: becau≈øe they ≈øee ≈øo many dye, they make the le≈ø≈øe reckoning of it: till death knocke at their owne doores, they never regard it: they mu≈øt needs dye them≈øelves, before they can bee brought to con≈øider of death: they care not who ≈øinke, ≈øo they ≈øwimme; nor how many die, ≈øo they may live: yea this is greatly to be lamented, that ≈øome doe regard the death of a Chri≈øtian, no more then they regard the death of a dog. But ≈øeeing wee may learne ≈øo many profitable in≈øtructions by their death, let us
now begin to con≈øider it better then ever we did before.

Others doe con≈øider it, but yet ami≈ø≈øe; either fondly, or frowardly. Fondly, through naturall affection ari≈øing from kindred, affinitie, or familiaritie. If a ≈øtranger die, it nothing moves them: but if one of their owne friends dye, they ≈øigh and ≈øob, they howle and lament. If the father lo≈øe his ≈øon, he cries mo≈øt pittifully, as David did for Ab≈øalom, O my ≈øon Ab≈øalom, my ≈øonne, my ≈øonne Ab≈øalom: would God I had died for thee: O Ab≈øalom my ≈øonne, my ≈øonne. If the mother lo≈øe her children, ≈øhee behaveth her ≈øelfe like Rachel weeping for her children, and would not be comforted, becau≈øe they were not. If children
lo≈øe their parents, they cry after them as Eli≈øha did after Elias, when he was taken up, my father, my father. If a ≈øi≈øter lo≈øe her brother, ≈øhe weepeth for him, as Mary did for Lazarus. If the husband lo≈øe his wife, he weepeth for her, as Abraham wept for Sarah: yea he mourneth like a Turtle Dove which hath lo≈øt his marrow. If the wife lo≈øe her husband, ≈øhee dealeth like Naomi, who would not be called Naomi, that is, beautifull: but Mara, that is, bitter, becau≈øe the Lord had given her much bitterne≈ø≈øe. If one familiar friend lo≈øe another, hee lamenteth his death, as David did the death of Ionathan: Woe is me for thee, my brother Ionathan: very kinde ha≈øt thou
beene unto me: thy love to mee was wonderfull, pa≈øsing the love of women.

Indeed I cannot deny, but that we ought in a ≈øpeciall manner to con≈øider the death of tho≈øe which are neere and deare unto us: for it may be they are taken from us, becau≈øe wee were unworthy of them; or becau≈øe we gloried and tru≈øted over much in them, and were not ≈øo thankfull for them as we ought. If we had any help by them, we mu≈øt con≈øider, whether God have not deptived us of them, for the puni≈øhment of our ≈øinnes, as the widow of Sarepta did at the death of her ≈øonne, ≈øaying unto Eliah: Art thou come unto me to call my ≈øinne to remembrance, and to ≈ølay my ≈øonne? Yet this con≈øideration

Neither mu≈øt wee con≈øider their death alone, but al≈øo the death of others which dye in the Lord, and to learne to make an holy u≈øe thereof. For as Samp≈øon found ≈øweet honey in the carca≈ø≈øe of a dead Lion; ≈øo wee may finde ≈øome ≈øweet in≈øtructions in the dead corps of every righteous man: yea the more righteous that they are which doe die, the more ≈øhould their death be con≈øidered, becau≈øe it may yeeld greater ≈øtore of in≈øtruction unto us. And it may bee, that God doth take away tho≈øe which are neare unto us, becau≈øe wee doe carele≈øly regard
the death of tho≈øe which be farre off.

Againe, ≈øome con≈øider the death of the righteous very frowardly and peevi≈øhly, yea I may ≈øay malitiou≈øly and prepo≈øterou≈øly. For if any of them bee taken away by a ≈øudden and extraordinary death, they pre≈øently cen≈øure them as plagued of God, and condemne their former profe≈ø≈øion, thinking that God would not have ≈øo dealt with them, if hee approved either of them or their profe≈ø≈øion. But they mu≈øt bee in≈øtructed in this point by wi≈øe Salomon, who ≈øaith: that no man knoweth love or hatred of all that is before him. ju≈øt and the wicked, to the good and the pure, and to the polluted: to him that ≈øacrificeth, and to him that ≈øacrificeth not. Eli was a Prie≈øt, and a good man; yet brake his necke by falling backward from his ≈øeat. Ionathan was a ≈øworne brother unto David, a godly and faithfull friend; yet was he ≈ølaine in battell by the hands of the Phili≈øtims. That Prophet of God which came out of Iudah to Bethel, to ≈øpeak with Ieroboam, and the altars which he had built for idolatry, was no doubt an holy man; yet was hee killed in the way by a Lion? Io≈øiah was a good King, like unto him there was no King before him, neither after him ro≈øe any like him: yet was

Iobs children were well brought up by their godly father, and it is ≈øaid that before Iob offered ≈øacrifice for them, they were ≈øanctified: yet within a while after, as they were eating and drinking in their elde≈øt brothers hou≈øe, a violent winde overthrew the hou≈øe, and killed them all.

2 Againe, if the righteous a little before death, bee dangerou≈øly tempted by Satan, and ≈øhew their infirmitie by uttering ≈øome ≈øpeeches which tend to doubting or de≈øperation (though afterward they get victorie, and triumph over the divel) carnall people think there is no peace of con≈øcience, and therefore no ≈øalvation to bee had, by that religion: and ≈øo ≈øpeake evill of it. Hee then tempted Chri≈øt, when hee was baptized and filled with the holy Gho≈øt: ≈øo will he mo≈øt tempt Chri≈øtians, when they have received greate≈øt gifts of Gods Spirit. div.p:
THe con≈øideration of the power of naturall love in the heart of Mankinde, hath of late induced me to write of divers things gathered out of the word of God, and other writings. But now having by the a≈ø≈øi≈øting grace of the Almighty, fully fini≈øhed three

emes, and an Annuall World, I thought good, for the ea≈øe of my minde, as my Vultimum vale to writing of ≈øuch my≈øteries, too high for my capacity to demon≈øtrate, to ≈øet downe the≈øe confu≈øed notions following. The fir≈øt ≈øhall bee the con≈øideration of Gods Providence towards his cho≈øen, in the examples of Iacob and David.
In the ≈øecond place, becau≈øe I began to write of the love of young men, I will conclude with the love of old men towards their children, in the examples of I≈øaac and Iacob.

In the fir≈øt I will ≈øhow, how God turned a Serpent, to a ≈øtaffe of ≈øupport, for the pre≈øervation of Iacob, and al≈øo how he made water to flow out of the hard Rocke‚ñ™ for the reliefe and refre≈øhment of David.

In the ≈øecond, I will declare and ≈øet forth, how aged parents (as in a gla≈ø≈øe) may ≈øee how to place and fix their love towards their children and kindred. In I≈øaacs love towards E≈øau, and in Iacobs
love towards Io≈øeph. But becau≈øe all the≈øe things are directly again≈øt the worldly-wi≈øe Politicians, e≈øpecially in the≈øe dangerous dayes, who are in be≈øt e≈øteeme, I thought it more ≈øafe for me, to de≈øi≈øt and ≈øtay my pen, le≈øt I too roughly handling that which is Noli me tangere, might incur ju≈øt reproofe and puni≈øhment for my labour. Yet becau≈øe I mentioned the≈øe things in Libro Amo ‚Ä¢ is, and other writings, and for that I doe not intend to ≈øtray from the Text of Scripture, but keepe clo≈øe to the genuine ≈øen≈øe of the word of God, ≈øo that none may find fault therewith, but they that applying it to them≈øelves find their galled backs hurt, or too gro≈øly toucht. I will not feare to goe forward, le≈øt it ≈øhould be ≈øaid, I have written that I was not able to make good. Therefore I will declare how the Serpent became a Rod, or ≈øtaffe of ≈øupport to Iacob. It is plain that I doe not meane that which was fir≈øt a Rod, then a Serpent, and la≈øt of all a Rod againe in the hand of Mo≈øes: neither doe I meane the Serpent that beguiled
our fir≈øt parents, or any other naturall Serpent. But I will write of Laban, as a Serpent: and to prove that hee had the properties and qualities that are in a Serpent, and ≈øo very well compared thereunto, I will divide him into three parts: fir≈øt his head, ≈øecondly his skinne, and la≈øt of all his ≈øting. Fir≈øt, that Laban had the head of a Serpent, viz. he was wi≈øe politique, and very crafty, is plaine. The Scripture te≈øtifies that the Serpent was more ≈øubtile then any bea≈øt of the field. And Chri≈øt exhorteth us to be wi≈øe as Serpents, both for the defence of our ≈øelves, and offence of our enemies. The Serpents wi≈øedome con≈øi≈øts in foure things. Fir≈øt, in the Spring ≈øhe ca≈øts off her old skin, and puts on a new: ≈øecondly, ≈øhe defends her head above all things: thirdly, ≈øhe ≈øtops her eares at the voice of the charmer: and la≈øtly, ≈øhe alwayes carries poi≈øon in her mouth, which ≈øhee expo≈øeth before ≈øhe drinkes. The application of this ≈øerpentine wi≈øedome I pa≈ø≈øe by. But affirme, that politicall wi≈øedome
for every man to bee provident. Fir≈øt, for his owne ≈øoules ≈øalvation: ≈øecondly, for his owne bodies health: and thirdly, for the welfare of his own family, is ≈øo far from reproofe, that it is worthy high commendation. And chiefly the fir≈øt. But how Laban was thus qualified, there's the quaere. For fir≈øt, it's plaine he was not ≈øo wi≈øe as he ≈øhould bee, hee did want that which is the true wi≈øedome, viz. fiduciall knowledge of the true God. Hee went a≈øtray out of the right way, according as his father Nahor before him had done and wor≈øhipped Images, the worke of mens hands, wood and ≈øtone. For when Rachel had ≈øtolne ≈øome of tho≈øe Images, he did exclaime again≈øt Iacob, that hee had ≈øtolne his gods: ≈øo when be made a covenant of peace with Iacob, he confirmed it with an oath, taking the god of Nahor to be his witne≈ø≈øe. And la≈øt of all, for the provi≈øion of his owne family, he was very carefull, and he that is not ≈øo, is wor≈øe then an infidell, even wor≈øe then Laban, for he was very covetous, and that appeares throughout the ≈øtory: for when Iacob had told him his arrand, viz. that hee had purcha≈øed the birthright of his elder brother, that he had obtained the ble≈ø≈øing of his father, that hee was ≈øent to him by his father and mother for a wife, that he had ≈øeene a vi≈øion by the way; and having according to his own agreement performed ≈øeven yeares for Rachel, he out of a ba≈øe covetous de≈øire, becau≈øe hee would not lo≈øe the benefit of Iacobs ≈øervice, cheated him with blear-ey'd Lea, and made him ≈øerve 7. yeares more for Rachel; for he thought, if Iacob had obtained his love, he would

Therefore finding that God ble≈ø≈øed him for Iacobs ≈øake, and as Iacob told him, ≈øaying, for the little that thou had≈øt before I came, is increa≈øed to a multitude, was very unwilling to part with Iacob, and therefore agreed with him upon a certaine bargaine of wages. But when hee ≈øaw that Iacob got too much that way, he abridged him of that, and changed his wages ten times: like many covetous ma≈øters in the≈øe dayes, that for feare their ≈øervants ≈øhould thrive under them, grow proud, or fit for better ≈øervices, doe what they can, as wel in abridging them of that which is their ju≈øt due, as ≈øometimes in tho≈øe things they may get without them, I meane without any damage or great trouble to them, as a word of their mouth, a note of their hand, or in performing the will of the dead. The skin of a Serpent is beautifull and gli≈øtering, and ≈øeemeth more amiable then hurtfull; and Laban as his name ≈øignifies White, the mo≈øt beautifull colour, ≈øo he ≈øeemed to bee a very faire dealing hone≈øt man, as by his oration to Iacob appeareth, in the≈øe words: What ha≈øt thou done? thou ha≈øt even ≈øtoln away my heart, and carried away my daughters as though they had beene taken captives with the ≈øword: wherefore did≈øt thou flie ≈øo ≈øecretly, and ≈øteale away from me, and did≈øt not tell me, that I might have ≈øent thee forth with mirth, and with ≈øongs, with Timbrell, and with Harpe: But thou ha≈øt not ≈øuffered mee to ki≈ø≈øe my ≈øonnes and my daughters. Now thou ha≈øt done fooli≈øhly in a ‚Ä¢ ng ≈øo: yet though thou w ‚Ä¢ nte≈øt away becau≈øe thou greatly longe≈øt after thy fathers hou≈øe, wherefore ha≈øt thou ≈øtolne away my gods? By which words any man of a rea≈øonable capacity would not otherwi≈øe apprehend, but
that Iacob had done him a great deale of wrong, and he no way faulty. But when he could not prove what he ≈øaid, then he was faine to condi≈øcend to the accu≈øation which Iacob laid to his charge. Yet becau≈øe he would ≈øeeme faultle≈ø≈øe, he claims propriety in his e≈øtate of all that hee had, in the≈øe words: The≈øe daughters are my daughters, the≈øe ≈øonne ‚Ä¢ are my ≈øonnes, and the≈øe ≈øheepe are my ≈øheepe, and all that thou ha≈øt is mine, and what can I not doe this day unto the≈øe my daughters, or to their ≈øonnes which they have borne? Like many Ma≈øters in the≈øe our dayes, that at their ≈øervants departure in ≈øtead of preferring or doing any good for them, charge them with ≈øuch things they cannot prove: then if they quit them≈øelves in that, they claim propriety in their e≈øtate, even as Laban in the≈øe or the like words, All the≈øe goods are ours, you have got them by us, and now you have got a little, you grow proud, but con≈øider, that if it had not beene by our meanes, you could never have come to this ≈øtate, as if they

The la≈øt part of Laban is his ≈øting, and that hath a poi≈øonous and venemous quality, and wounds deadly. Which was the envious heart of Laban his intents to hurt Iacob.
